episode.title: San Diego Gas & Electric Company v. City of San Diego

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments in San Diego Gas & Electric Company v. City of San Diego.
Mr. Goebel, you may proceed when you're ready.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Our case this morning deals with the availability of a money damage remedy for just compensation when the oppressive governmental conduct of a municipality denies a property owner of all practical beneficial or economic use of his property.

In particular, this case presents a question which was left open by the decision of this Court last term in Agins v. City of Tiburon, namely, whether a state may limit a property owner under such circumstances to solely nonmonetary or so-called equitable remedies.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But your premise is that there was a taking in this case?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
We believe there was a taking.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But that's disputed, I suppose?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: It is disputed.
We--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And if we agreed with your opposition we wouldn't reach the question again.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's possible, Your Honor.
In this case we had a fully developed trial record as opposed to the Agins case.
The trial court found a taking and that taking was affirmed by the California Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, am I wrong that the latest order of the intermediate appellate court leaves open the question whether there was a taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I don't believe--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Initially, there was a finding, you know, that there was a taking, both by the initial court and by the appellate division, was there not?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: But then I thought, when... what's this strange practice of a transfer by your Supreme Court to the appellate court?
That's not a remand, or is it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: It's a... it is, in effect, a remand of the same case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, does it vacate the judgment clause?
Did the transfer vacate the affirmance of the finding of taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, but under California practice it would have been vacated anyway.

In this case, after the California Court of Appeal, the intermediate appellate court, affirmed the trial court judgment, the Supreme Court granted a hearing, which has the effect of vacating the intermediate appellate court's opinion anyway.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, and then, doesn't the appellate court send it back leaving still open the question of taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: They sent it back for reconsideration in light of their Agins decision.
Now, it's our position that there was no question at that point in time what the basis for the second California Court of Appeal decision was.
The California Court of--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: See, what I'm reaching at, is there a final judgment here?
That's... do we have jurisdiction at all?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Well, I think you do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: On the taking question?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: In regard to this taking away this judgment, the California Court of Appeal specifically stated that a local agency's arbitrary, unconstitutional exercise of the police power does not require compensation.
It was that premise which caused the California Court of Appeal to do a 180 and suddenly take away the judgment which only months before they had affirmed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, this is an appeal from the Court of Appeal's judgment?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Because any further appeal was refused?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: The second time around, so to speak, the California Supreme Court denied hearing, and therefore we brought this appeal to this Court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Goebel, your client, as I understand it, wants to build a power plant on this land.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Your Honor, that was the original intention at the time of acquisition of this property in 1966.
However--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: The taking, the theory of the taking, is that you're denied the right to build the plant you planned on building?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Build the plant or some other industrial use.
the property was acquired--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, supposing, when the case goes back to the trial court, the trial court enters an order that says, let them build either a power plant or some other industrial use.
Would you be complaining about that?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --As it happens... I'll answer that on two levels, Your Honor.
As it happens, the plans of my client have changed in the intervening years and there's no longer a desire to build a power plant.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: What do you want to use the land for?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: To devote the property to a use that was perfectly consistent with the zoning and planning at the time they acquired it, some industrial use.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Give me an example of what you'd like to use the land for?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: A well-planned, designed industrial park.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: All right.

Supposing, when you go back, the trial judge enters an order and says that this would be an unconstitutional taking unless the property owner is permitted to build precisely that, and you will argue for the right to do that?
You do have the right to do that on remand, don't you?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's not the California practice as I understand it, Your Honor.

The California practice for these so... called equitable remedies is that if the court, the judicial system finds the action previously taken by the municipality to be improper, the case is simply remanded to the municipality for, to be dealt with entirely anew.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: You don't think you get any relief at all on remand?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: We'd have an opportunity--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Would you have an opportunity on remand to ask the judge to say, please enter an order that will allow us to develop this as an industrial park?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That is not the practice under administrative relief.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: I know it's not the practice, but you've claimed your constitutional rights have been denied you.
And in order to remedy the constitutional rights, you say the only thing that will protect us is to let us build this industrial park.
Would he have power to grant you that relief?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I assume there is power and jurisdiction to grant that relief, Your Honor.
It's not the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: How do we know he's not going to do it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --I think that in light of the decision in the Agins case and in our case when it was previously before the courts, that that's not likely to happen.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Goebel, what's the significance of that sentence in the second opinion of the appellate court,
"The City has not made application to use or improve the property, nor has it asked the City what development might be permitted. "
What's that all about?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: It sounds like you didn't exhaust your administrative remedies.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Your Honor, it is correct that the property owner has not submitted a specific development proposal to the City and been denied.
It is our position on this record, on the factual record developed in the trial court, that to have done so was totally impractical and futile.
That was so found by the trial court, and affirmed by the Court of Appeal in the first instance.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, why does the Court of Appeal throw this in in the second opinion?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I'm not certain, Your Honor.

I think in the context of this remand and the statement that I read to Your Honor previously, that it is clear that the action of the Court of Appeal, what caused the Court of Appeal on the same record to take a 180 difference in view was the fact that the California Supreme Court had said, even an arbitrary, unconstitutional exercise of the police power does not require compensation.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Let me be a little more specific.
When did your client, the utility, reach the decision not to build these nuclear plants?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: It would have been in the early '70s, Your Honor, prior to the--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Do you know what the basis of that decision was?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --A number of changing concerns by the Company, and also the changing regulatory climate in California in terms of environmental constraints, building power plants near the ocean, and so forth.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Have you ever tried to sell any of the property in question?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Not prior to the trial of this action, Your Honor.

However, there was a finding of fact in the trial court that after the culmination of the several aspects of the City's conduct, the property was unmarketable and had only a nominal fair market value.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Have you had any offers to purchase?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: But, in any event, the appellant never sought approval for a nuclear plant?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

And it is our position that in effect, as a matter of law, beyond dispute, at the conclusion of the totality of the City's conduct in June of 1973, would have been totally impractical and futile to do so by reason of the consistency policy which the City had followed.

And that is that when they enacted an open space designation on a particular property, they required any building permit and any subdivision map on that property to be consistent with the open space designation.
We say, how can any industrial use be consistent with open space?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: And yet they purported to bring within the possibility a nuclear power plant.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: We believe that was a cynical--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, tell me, Mr. Goebel, could the City, I take it, repeal this ordinance?
It could now, couldn't it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --It could repeal it and modify it; yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, suppose it repealed it.
Then I take it you'd be free or your client would be free to go ahead and build its nuclear power with no inhibition in this ordinance.

Now, if that were to happen, would the holding as to compensation mean you could not have compensation for the period that you've been denied the use of the property to build a nuclear plant, whatever that period is, a year or two, something?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Since that was not the case before the Court, we can't say for sure, Your Honor.
There is not any significant precedent in California for interim damages in this kind of a situation.
The typical situation where there's a remand and an invalidation is no interim damages.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Isn't Agins itself a precedent?
It says you don't collect damages, you seek a writ of mandate.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Agins is the controlling precedent, and in our view that's the precedent that caused the Court of Appeal to do a 180 and--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: But Agins is not before us, is it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Agins is not before us, is it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: No, Your Honor, you disposed--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Don't you really want us to reverse Agins?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --I want you to declare--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: We can't do it, I don't think.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, I don't think that's true.
But you--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Well, isn't that really what you want?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --In Agins, this Court, as I understand the opinion, found that there was no taking, and therefore did not reach the question of whether a state could limit a property owner whose property has been taken by regulatory conduct to equitable remedies only.
We don't ask that you reverse Agins.
We simply ask that you confirm that the Fifth Amendment means what it says, that when there's a taking of property, that just compensation is required, and just compensation means money damages.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Well, you want us to write an essay?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: No, Your Honor, we'd simply like to have the money judgment affirmed on the basis of the Fifth Amendment and settle precedent of this Court from Pennsylvania Coal to Penn Central.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Suppose you agreed with me that... or agreed with the suggestion that there is no final decision on taking in the California courts.
Wouldn't Agins suggest that perhaps we shouldn't decide the inverse condemnation question, that we should just say, there is no taking?
Or remand until... or just don't decide the case until there is a decision on the taking issue?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well, that's a possibility, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, then, where do you... where do you put your finger on a final decision that there is a taking, in the California courts?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I can't put my finger on the fact that there is a final decision of the California courts that there is a taking.
My position is that there was a taking in California established in the trial court and affirmed on the Court of Appeal until the California Supreme Court changed things.
It was that part of the judgment--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, that finding was never disavowed or reversed, was it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --In effect it was, because the consequence of that taking, that is, the flowing of money damages under the Fifth Amendment, was taken away by the Court of Appeal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, your California court has held that when a taking is the result of the unconstitutional and arbitrary use of the exercise of the police power, there is no condemnation, although I expect that it would hold that when the taking is the result of the wholly legitimate use of the taking power, there is.
It's rather odd.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, and we think it is totally in violation with the Fifth Amendment and the settled precedents of this Court--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In other words, you don't have to claim, it seems to me, under the Just Compensation Clause that this taking was wrongful in any way.
Because the Just Compensation Clause assumes that it was a rightful taking.
You take... the government takes private property for the use of building a post office or a city hall, or a public park.
And it can be quite legitimate.
You're still constitutionally entitled to compensation, even if the taking is wholly rightful.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But your California court has held, presumably, that while you are entitled to compensation when the taking is wholly rightful, you're not entitled to it when the taking is wrongful.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: We view that as a very bizarre--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It is bizarre, if that's the--

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --position, Your Honor, and furthermore, I want to--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --Does that correctly characterize it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --I think so.
I want to make it clear in this case that we're not dealing solely with a state claim.
We're dealing here with a claim which was also found to be a federal constitutional tort.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Goebel, will you give me in the record exactly what you're appealing from?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: We're appealing from the--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: I'm speaking of an order or... or something that looks like an order.
Because I don't know what we've got here yet.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Judgment of the Court of Appeal on the second occasion, Your Honor, which is found in the Joint Appendix.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: G1 of your jurisdictional statement.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Of the jurisdictional statement.
It is also found in the Joint Appendix at page 63.

But it's our position that this cause of action that was litigated, found by the trial court and affirmed by the Court of Appeal, was not only a state cause of action but a federal constitutional tort, whether we call it common law inverse condemnation, a Bivens tort, or in effect a 1983 civil rights cause of action.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, it seems to me that you're mixing up two things.
The Just Compensation Clause of the Constitution, of the Fifth Amendment, as incorporated in the Fourteenth for the purposes of this case, presumes a perfectly lawful taking, not a tort at all.
It is simply an exercise of the power of government, of its eminent domain power, to take up private property for public purposes.
Why do you have to also assume that this was an improper taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well, I won't... if I was not faced with the bizarre position of the California Supreme Court, I wouldn't have to take that position.

I'm only taking that position because I think that it's inconsistent with this Court's position in Owen v. the City of Independence to have an unconstitutional act of government not be... utilize money damages.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, you're suggesting its wrongful only in the sense they didn't give you any money?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, that's all right.
And that's your claim.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's the essence of it, Your Honor, whatever label we put on it, it--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But assume that it was perfectly clear in the California courts that the courts had decided, (a) there is a taking; (b) that you're not entitled to any money, however; you're entitled only to an injunction.
Now, let's just assume that.
Wouldn't both issues be open here, whether there is a taking for federal constitutional purposes, and then only if there were, would we reach the other question?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --I don't believe so, Your Honor, because the sole question that's open in California courts as I understand it is the question of whether declaratory or equitable relief might be available.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes, but we don't need to accept the California court's holding that there is a taking for Fifth Amendment purposes, Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment purposes?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And so, isn't the other side entitled to insist on an affirmance based on the ground that there is not a taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: If you don't accept the California court's position on taking, it's my position that we proved in the trial court... and you can examine the record and affirm... that there was a taking.
It's a mixed question of fact and law.
You can look at the trial record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But you lost below?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: No, we won below.
We proved--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: No, but you lost... you're an appellant here.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: No matter how far below you go.
The last judgment was against you?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So you were a loser.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Only in that court, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Yes, where you were a loser.
But the... but isn't the other side entitled to say that you should continue to lose and that the last judgment that's being appealed should be affirmed on the ground that there was not a taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I don't understand that to be the proper result, Your Honor.
If the facts in the record establish that there was such conduct by the government and compensation ought to be paid.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes, but isn't that question open here?
For us to decide?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: The only question that remains for the California courts to decide is whether or not they will choose on the basis of these facts to grant equitable relief.
We say that even if they decide to grant equitable relief, that's not constitutionally adequate, because the Fifth Amendment requires more.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: You need more money?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: We want money, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: That's what you want, money.

Mr. Goebel, your second and third cause of action in your complaint were petitions for mandate and the relief prayed in paragraph 3 of your complaint was that the Court order the City of San Diego to set aside the rezoning and to set aside the adoption of the open space element of its general plan.
As I understand it, on remand, the trial court may grant that relief, theoretically.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Now, if they grant that relief, how could there then have been a taking?
Aren't the things that are set aside the things on which you rely to establish the taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but it's our position that the first cause of action established that a taking occurred and that we were entitled to litigate that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: You're making sort of a law of the case, are you?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --In state court, even... well, regardless of state law, we're entitled to litigate the federal constitutional tort aspect of those facts in state court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Let me put it more simply.
If you get the relief you prayed for in paragraph 3 of your complaint, would you still contend there had been a taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Of what?
You have a total right to use your property any way you want to.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: But we have seven years after that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, you might have a damage action for the loss of the use of the property in the seven years, but you have not alleged any intent to use the property in this period of time.
All you describe here is some long-range plan in the future that you say was denied you.
Maybe you could amend your complaint to get damages, but I don't understand how there's a taking if you set aside that which constituted the taking?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, it's our position that the so-called set-aside, those equitable remedies are constitutionally inadequate to remedy the nexus of combination of facts which result in what we allege to be a taking.
That remedy is simply inadequate.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But if, when this case goes back, if it goes back, the trial court can find that you can build whatever you could have built initially, before the zoning change, haven't you got all the relief that you are entitled to?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor.
I think we're entitled to--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: The interim damages too?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Interim damages.
And I don't think that really puts us back in our position, because we're now, by that time we'd be--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but are you entitled to the interim damages as the consequence of a taking, or just of deprivation of use for the seven or eight years?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --If we are to accept the California Supreme Court's dichotomy between these two concepts, I think we're left with the interim damages as a result of the interim deprivation of use.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: It's not consequent upon a taking if the ordinance that caused all the trouble, the difficulty for you.
If that's invalidated, then there's no taking, is there?
You'll be free to go ahead and erect your nuclear plant.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: When that finally becomes a fact, it'll be ten to fifteen years after the fact of the events that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: You may have a claim for damages in ten or fifteen years.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --But, as possible, I would hope that the Fifth Amendment--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: I thought a taking usually meant, as my brother Stewart suggested earlier, the government, whatever the unit may be, ends up with the property and you end up with money.
Right.
And if the government doesn't end up with the property, because the ordinance is invalidated, then you keep the property.
You can build your plant, and if you have any claim, why is it anything more than damages?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Your Honor, if you get a chance to go through the facts of this case, it's our position that we're not dealing with a single ordinance or even two or three ordinances.

We're dealing with the synergistic effect of a course of conduct which resulted in a taking, much along the formulation that was very well discussed in the Penn Central case, that these cases are to be decided on an ad hoc case-by-case determination.
And when you take into consideration all the aspects and elements of the course of conduct of the City of San Diego in this instance, it constitutes a taking.

That includes not just one ordinance, not just two ordinances, it includes the fact that they passed a resolution of public convenience and necessity to acquire this property for public use; it includes the fact that the trial court found, as a matter of fact, that the property is now being devoted to public use, because in fact the public use originally sought was open space and a person now driving along the interstate freeway next to this property uses the property for the very purpose that it was originally sought by resolution of public convenience and necessity.

It's that synergistic effect of this course of conduct that we claim entitles us to compensation and it's that synergistic effect which we also assert renders the equitable remedies, or the so-called equitable remedies, inadequate.
There has been a great deal of discussion of these so-called equitable remedies, and again, we believe that they are inadequate.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Goebel, let me ask you one question about the last paragraph of the opinion of the supreme court of California, F14 in the blue brief, where it says,

"Recognizing that constitutionally protected property interest is here involved, we also accept the reasonable latitude which must be afforded public officials on planning for implementation of legitimate land use goals. "
"These twin purposes will be served by preserving to the landowner in appropriate cases declaratory relief or mandamus remedies. "
"However, the use of inverse condemnation with its imposition of money damages upon the public entity would in our view unwisely inhibit the proper and necessary exercise of a valid police power. "
Now, do you read that to say that money damages are simply not recoverable regardless of how arbitrary the zoning of the city was?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's my understanding, Your Honor, and that certainly was the understanding of the California Court of Appeal.
They said it in so many words, at page 13 of the reply brief, or page 66 of the Joint Appendix:
"A local entity's arbitrary, unconstitutional exercise of the police power which deprives the owner of the beneficial use of his land does not require compensation. "
They said it point-blank.
That's the rule in California as we understand it.
And it's that rule that violates the federal Constitution in our view, and that's why we're asking this Court to act.
But, further on the question of the adequacy of--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But it... to be complete, it should have said, but of course he can get his property back.
Or, the restrictions may be invalidated.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's true.
It goes on to say that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: It offers the property owners--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But it doesn't leave the property owner without any remedy whatsoever.
He can get the restrictions invalidated.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's correct.
We view that offer to be an illusory offer not adequate and not--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, it isn't illusory.
It's just that meanwhile you can't use your property.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --It's not fully--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Which is a substantial matter, but it doesn't mean you can't use it forever.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --It's not the full equivalent of the property taken, that this Court has repeatedly held is required under the Fifth Amendment from the Monongahela case on down.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, did the Court of Appeal just right out, as you say, indicate that there are no interim damages either?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: They didn't deal with that question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, that's... so your answer is, no, they did not say that?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: They did not say one way or the other.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: So that, let's assume that the California courts would say, you can't get... make us buy the property at the fair market value, but we'll give you an injunction against further enforcement of the restrictions and we'll give you interim damages.
And would you still say, well, we have the right to have you buy the property from us?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: On the basis of an ad hoc case-by-case determination we think there is still a category of cases where the only satisfactory remedy is money damages.
We're not saying that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But you mean, for the whole property?
For the entire property?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --For the property.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: They would have to take title to the property and pay you for it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: When you have, as in this case, a combination of four or five factors which through their own synergy come together and have the impact that we claim was present in this case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather, Mr. Goebel, your client's no longer interested in building the plant; let the City keep the property; it wants the money.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct.
But again, as the trial court found and as we assert--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, can't the City back out if it wants to?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That question really hasn't been dealt with in California.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know, but can't it?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I would think that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: It would be compelled to, I take it, if the courts were to invalidate this synergistic combination that you have.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --If you could do such a thing, Your Honor; if such a thing were possible.
And that's part of the reason why we say, at least in a certain category of cases the money damage remedy is the only appropriate one.

Again I refer to the Owen v. City of Independence case where it was stated that a decisionmaker would be derelict in his duties if he didn't at some point consider whether his decision comports with constitutional mandates and didn't weigh the risk that a violation might have an effect upon the public treasure.
It's this cost-benefit--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It's not clear to me, and maybe I'm repeating myself, but it's not clear to me whether you argue that your client's entitled to money damages for a wrongful act of San Diego, or whether you're simply entitled to compensation because San Diego has taken your real property.
Now, there is a difference.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Let me try to address that without getting bound up in semantics, Your Honor.
It is our view that the Fifth Amendment requires compensation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Whether it's by reason of constitutional or unconstitutional acts.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: There is a difference, but compensation results from a perfectly rightful taking of property.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: In our view, the combination of the facts and circumstances of this case led to in June of 1973 a taking of this property.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So if it had been a perfectly valid exercise of the police power that would have taken your property, you would not have questioned the exercise of the police power, you would have simply said, please pay me for the property you've taken.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Not for any wrongful action on the part of San Diego, except insofar as it was wrong to not pay you.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Wrong to not pay.
That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Right.
Mr. Goebel, it's of course perfectly clear that if a sovereign takes and keeps property, he's got to pay for it.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: If he takes it rightfully.

But is there any precedent at all that you've cited where the government has impaired the use of private property in attempting to serve some governmental purpose, and its action has later been held unconstitutional, and it's been required to pay money to the property owner?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Owen--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Owen isn't such a case.
Owen is an individual discharge.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --That's right.
There are a number of cases at the lower federal level.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: But this Court has never held there's any such obligation?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: It's stated the principle in a number of cases from Pennsylvania Coal to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: No, no, those are all rightful... those are all cases where it's held that the sovereign had the power to do what it sought to do.
Now, you rely on a Mr. Justice Stewart points out... theory.

Is there any case where the government has acted wrongfully and the consequence of its wrong has been to impair the use of property and the government's had to pay the property owner money for its wrong?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Well, I think that's implicit in the Fifth Amendment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, the Fifth Amendment deals with rightful taking, for the moment.
If this... have you got any case at all for your position, involving a wrongful interference with the use of property, where the government was required to pay the property owner even a dime?

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well, I think that's implicit in the Kaiser Aetna decision.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: We used to have cases like that quite frequently in the Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit, where the claim was made that the government exceeded its authorized power in exercising its power of eminent domain for the purpose of taking something, not for a post office but for some marginal purpose.
And the issue was, had the government rightfully exercised its power of eminent domain?
And sometimes it was decided that it had, sometimes it was decided that it hadn't.

When it was decided that it hadn't, then the property owner was always entitled to damages for the tying up of his property during the period that the case was between the government decided to take it and the time the case was decided.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well, the U.S. v. Causby is a similar case, except, of course, the appellants would say that involved aspects of physical invasion.
But that's the type of case.
There are a number of cases.
Each case is different, though.
That's why we've led to the standard that it's an ad hoc case by case determination.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: No, in Causby it was held that the government was within its rights in flying the airplanes over the property, and that what it did was rightful but it caused harm, and therefore was a taking and it had to pay for it.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: Well, I don't want to be led into the position that we're asserting by reason of your interpretation, the interpretation we're leading to here on the Fifth Amendment, that we're asserting this is a wrongful taking.
Perhaps if we approach it salami style and slice it up a piece at a time--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, in the second and third counts of your complaint you do, you allege... in your petition for mandate you allege it was wrongful.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: --Wrongful in the sense that they did it and they didn't pay for it.
In effect, our position is, this property has been devoted to public use since 1973, has served its purpose, the same purpose they wanted to condemn it for in the first place.
It's open space.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: You have an action for rent.

turn.speaker: louis_e_goebel
turn.label: Mr. Louis E. Goebel
turn.text: I'd like to reserve the rest of my time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your time is entirely used up, counsel.
Mr. Sumption.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
Briefly, I'd like to go over some of what I consider to be the important relevant facts in this case, because--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: At some point will you tell us what is the scope of the authority of the trial court, assuming this case went back?
What can it do?
Do it in your own time, but tell us about it sometime.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --All right, Your Honor.
Thank you.
And if I neglect to answer your question, would you please remind me?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: We'll bring it up again.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I think the facts are crucial to get a grasp of what this case is all about, because we've got a number of confusing facts and a number of shifting and conflicting theories of liability and seeking of relief against the City of San Diego.
We're talking about land use regulation by way of zoning on approximately half of the 214 acres of the property that the trial court said we had taken.

We're talking about land use activity by way of planning, as opposed to zoning, by the adoption of an open space plan, mandated by the State of California, required by all local governments, to attempt to plan for the preservation, whether it be through regulation or acquisition, of open space lands that are currently being diminished in the State of California.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Does the plan forbid the owner to make anything of an open space without the approval of the municipal plan?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: That's one of the issues that's in contention, Your Honor.
It's our position it does not.

The definitions cited in the open space plan, there's really no one single definition, but the plan recites that for most purposes the definition is something to the effect that the property shown as open space should remain in it's essential, natural, or in an open, condition.
The City of San Diego interprets that to mean, not that no development is reasonable or inconsistent with open space.
In fact, the City of San Diego has allowed developments notwithstanding an open space designation, where we did not have the resources to purchase the property.
And that's one of the major issues, I think, in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's a factual issue, and this Court isn't here to decide factual issues.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, except in the circumstance of this case and the way it's come up, the City of San Diego appealed the trial court's findings of fact in the Court of Appeal and on up on the basis that there was no substantial evidence to support them, and the question, the findings on a taking, and the question of whether or not the Gas & Electric Company was excused from applying for some relief to avoid the problem that this Court saw in the Agins case, are really so intertwined and mixed with legal questions that I don't think you can completely separate them out from factual findings.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, it's certainly not a factual question to say that if the City says that the 214 acres of the San Diego power company land that's presently open is hereafter a park with access to everybody, and no compensation is to be paid.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: The plan does not say that, and nothing the City of San Diego did or said contemplated that public use could be made of this property designated for open space.
There is--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Isn't that the definition of open space, isn't that a public--

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --It's to preserve land from being developed or overdeveloped and lost forever.
It might be used for X... excuse me.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: --What's the difference if they declared it a park and put a lot of park benches in it and let the public use it?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: The difference would be that the public is then actually using the property.
And that's one of the bases for the distinction between the power of eminent domain and the police power used to regulate land use by prohibiting certain natural excuses.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: But are you telling us now that the public is not using it by--

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: The public is not using it in any physical, sense.
The property was vacant before the City of San Diego designated it for potential acquisition in its open space plan.
It was unused and the public was enjoying it by driving by the freeway and looking out to the ocean then just as much as in the--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --Are you saying that any members of the public who came on this land after it had been declared open land would have been trespassers?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Against whom the electric company should proceed?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Absolutely right.
The public had no right to go on that property.
We did not require there be any paths, pedestrian hikers' trails, bicycle paths, anything of that sort.
It was merely to preserve and protect land that otherwise would have been developed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: What would the City have done had the utility attempted to develop the 214 acres in a way you would normally expect a utility to normally develop such acreage?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Your Honor, that's something that from this record we don't know and we will never know until the Gas & Electric Company comes to the City and gives it the opportunity to interpret its own actions, its own open space plan, to weigh and balance the important public interest versus the private property interest of this landowner to determine what is a reasonable use of the property, whether or not we want to preclude all use of it by purchasing it so that it's now in the public domain and we can do with it what we want, or whether we will allow some use that we consider to be consistent with open spaces.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Including construction of a nuclear plant?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Including... especially including the construction of a nuclear plant.
The open space plan itself specifically says that there shall not be any per se incompatibility between properly building and siting a nuclear power plant on this property.

And to that extent the Gas & Electric Company simply cannot start switching its expectations and claiming that we had somehow deceived them because we knew they had bought the property for construction of a power plant and that we somehow pulled the rug out from under them.
The first time we ever heard that the Gas & Electric Company was thinking of other industrial uses for this property was at trial when they paraded out an industrial park development plan.
They had never gone to the city planners, the staff, or the City Council and said, what do you think about the possibility of us doing this?
We can no longer use the property for a power plant site.

Furthermore, our zoning regulations allowed by conditional use permit, they could have built... they could make any use that a public utility can do by way of structures, buildings, or uses, by conditional use permit.

Even on the agricultural zoned portions of the property, which were zoned agricultural when they bought the property, half of it was zoned industrial when they bought it, half of it was zoned for agricultural purposes.
They could have come in and made use by way of conditional use permit if they had applied for scientific and other--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, your brother is shaking his head, and these are factual controversies that it's no business of this Court to try to resolve.
We're simply not equipped to do it.
Mr. Sumption?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: You commenced your brief, as I recall, by saying that the findings of fact made by the trial court had been rejected.
Where in any opinion is that made clear?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: The only place, Your Honor, where... well, first of all, from a procedural standpoint in California law, when the case... the first opinion was decided by the California Court of Appeal, we sought further appeal by way of a hearing in the California Supreme Court.

When the California Supreme Court granted that hearing under California procedure, that vacates and renders null and void without any force and effect the Court of Appeal opinion which had affirmed the trial court's findings.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But not the Superior Court opinion?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is gone.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought the Supreme Court of California in ordinary proceedings vacated the intermediate appellate court opinion, but left standing, reversed, or affirmed the Superior Court opinion?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't believe that's so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, just a granting of a hearing doesn't vacate the findings of the Superior Court.
Is that what you're suggesting?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Well, it vacates the Court of Appeal opinion.
From that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes, that's... suppose that it had set aside the findings?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
I didn't follow that question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Suppose the intermediate court had set aside the findings of the trial court?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes; which we had asked them to do.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And suppose it had... and then there's a grant of a hearing by the California Supreme Court, which vacates the judgment of the intermediate appellate court, doesn't that reinstate the findings of the trial court?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Perhaps there's a semantical difference, but it doesn't... my understanding is it does not reinstate them, the court is still open to determine from the record whether there is evidence to support those findings of fact.
And we contended that there was no--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, they aren't vacated until and unless they reinstate them, are they?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Well, that could be, Your Honor.

But then the next thing that happened, that leads to my conclusion that they have in fact been vacated, is this paragraph that we've been dealing with by the Court of Appeal's second opinion after the case was retransferred back to the Court of Appeal after the California Supreme--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Now, is transfer a peculiar procedure in California?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think transfer and remand, as far as I can tell, are one and the same.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Same thing?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't know why they use the different terminology, because the California Supreme Court, I think, does use "remand" as well.

But when the case went back, it's not a... obviously, from reading it, it's not a model of clarity, but I can see no other interpretation from the language, especially when we were contending that the Gas & Electric Company had never applied for any relief, that this zoning had never been applied to them, and in light of the California Supreme Court's decision in the Agins case, then it goes back to the Court of Appeal and they expressly state that they have not applied for any relief.
Why would they make this--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Was that the sentence quoted earlier?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Yes.
Why would the court make that statement if they didn't feel that there was merit to our contention that they had not been legally excused from seeking application?
There was no concrete controversy before the court.

Then it, to reinforce that argument, it goes on a little bit further in that same paragraph and it said, its remedy if any for alleged overzealous use of the police power would be equitable relief other than money damages.
And the Company did in its complaint seek these remedies, asserting that the City had arbitrarily exercised its police power by enacting an unconstitutional zoning law and general plan elements.
And then it says, "or by applying the zoning".

However, on the present record, these are disputed fact issues not covered, so I read that as the Court of Appeal saying there is no sufficient evidence on this record from which the gas company's argument that we had applied these regulations arbitrarily is supported.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And what then do you understand the Court of Appeal required the Superior Court now to do?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: They go on to say that if the Gas & Electric Company wants to pursue its equitable remedies, to set aside these land use and planning decisions, that they... because there's not sufficient evidence in the existing record... they can retry that issue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Retry the taking issue?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Retry the taking issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: In court, or do they have to dismiss the case and start with the City?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't know that they have to dismiss the case.
I think they're back to the trial court and they can pursue their case on the existing complaint on--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: So they have exhausted their administrative remedies, so to speak?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --They had not.
That would be one of the issues as to whether or not there was a taking.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, I would think you would have dismissed the case until they had.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
You're right.

In other words, they should not be able to pursue their judicial remedies until they have exhausted their administrative remedies, which means finding out from the City of San Diego what they might or might not be able to do with this property.

Then, if the conclusion results that there's no reasonable use that the city's going to allow them, because we want to buy this property for open space, they can... you know, they've exhausted their relief, and the court will not have to sit as a planning board or body, the trial court, as it did in the first trial of this case, and it can determine whether or not there was a taking and if there was a taking, what follows?
What's the remedy?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Sumption, let's come back to the facts that were found by the trial court and affirmed by the Court of Appeal, one of which was that it would be perfectly futile to do what you call exhaust administrative remedies.
Now, was there ever any finding by an appellate court anywhere that there was no substantial evidence to support that finding by the trial court?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Not in those specific words, Your Honor.
And that's why it's--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, aren't you relying on an inference when there were originally two findings, or rather finding by the trial court and acceptance of that finding by the California intermediate appellate court, that it would have been futile?
The California Supreme Court didn't say anything to the contrary.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Well, the California Supreme Court never really answered any question.
They simply sent the case back after they decided Agins by saying, take another look at it now after we've told you what the law is.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Are you saying that all findings have been vacated in this case?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: As far as the taking question which in... a subsidiary question of whether there was a taking and the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, and the futility--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Could you identify by number the findings that have been vacated?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --It would take me a few minutes to flip through the pages to find the specific--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Everything relevant to this case has been vacated, is that your position?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --It would be the finding that there was a denial of all reasonable use of the property, and that it would have been futile for the Gas & Electric Company to have applied for any development.
Those are the--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: The only basis for your argument, I judge from what you have said, is the final paragraph in the four-page opinion of the Court of Appeal on its second consideration of this case?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, I can see no reason why the court would have said that they have not applied for any relief or found out what they could do with the property, unless they meant--

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: There's nothing in that paragraph as I read it that rejects Finding No. 29, which in substance says that the owner already has been deprived of all practical use of his property.
What language in that paragraph states?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --No, there's nothing specific that says that.
They don't refer to any findings either generally... either by the word "findings" or by the number, specifically.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: I thought, Mr.... in reading these briefs, under California law, everything that the trial court says is wiped out, as thought it hadn't been said at all, and everything that the Court of Appeal said in its first opinion is wiped out.
Is that correct as a matter of California law?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Everything that the Court of Appeal said is wiped out, in its first opinion.
That is gone.
Now--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It's gone as though it had never been written.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --That's right.

And so, you eliminate that and then you take what the Court of Appeal is saying on its second opinion that's being appealed from, and they are mentioning the fact that they have not applied for any relief.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What I don't understand is that the California Supreme Court decision in Agins didn't deal at all with these factual findings.
Did... and I say this from principles of law, that it would appear caused it to remand this case to the Court of Appeal.
There was no rejection by the California Supreme Court of the findings, and no review, again, of findings by your intermediate appellate court.
If there's any authority in your brief that says that all facts are wiped out in those circumstances, that may be another thing.
We took the case because we thought it was different from Agins.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I realize that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: But you are now arguing that inferentially this is entirely a new ball game?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I think Agins applies and is controlling precedent in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, here's what your Court of Appeal said in the opinion supporting the judgment that is appealed from here, at the end of its penultimate paragraph:
"A local entity's arbitrary unconstitutional exercise of the police power which deprives the owner of the beneficial use of his land does not require compensation. "
That's the way they understand the law of California, and isn't that the issue before us?
Whether or not that's correct, as a matter of federal constitutional law?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't think the Court can get to that issue without finding that there was a taking, and--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the Court of Appeal certainly got to it, and disposed of it.
They also got to the taking question.
You took the same position in the lower courts and you lost.
They didn't... they said, whatever the Company should or shouldn't have done, we nevertheless... there is no barrier to our reaching the taking question.
They reached it.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --I realize that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: They said there was a taking.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I realize that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Or at least a full deprivation of the use of the property.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: And I think they were dead wrong--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I know you do.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --on that, and there's no evidence to support that finding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I know you do, but you lost that in the state courts.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: But now, with the Court of Appeal's second opinion, they seem to be retracting from that position--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, it doesn't sound like it from what Justice Stewart read.
It sounds like they stuck right to their guns.
Well, but, don't you have to read the opinion in the light of the allegations of the complaint?
Didn't the appellate courts as a matter of law in effect hold that Count One of the complaint does not state a cause of action.
That's the only count on which they ask for damages and that was the taking theory, compensation for the taking.
There was no allegation in the complaint asking for interim damages, so there was no occasion for the courts of appeals to rule on whether not damages for loss of interim use would be recoverable.
Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Interim damages were not raised at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Nobody ever raised or argued about it at all, and so all of the language is broad.
As Justice Stewart says, it's not directed to the complaint.
Well, but if there were a taking, a perfectly valid taking under California law, interim damages would follow with general damages under the taking clause, would it not?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: No, I don't believe that interim damages would necessarily be awarded under the taking clause if--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean, you think the City could announce that as of January 1, 1973, this particular 215 acres is a park to which all of the citizens of California shall have access, and then on January 1, 1978, five years later, pay the company the fair value of the park?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --That's my understanding of the law in California, plus seven percent interest per annum from the date of the taking, plus attorneys' fees and expert witness fees, if they have to go to court to prove that there was a taking.
But I would caution Your Honor that that's not the facts in this case, as far as us declaring that that was a park.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then don't you have to disavow part of the Court of Appeal's opinion?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: On what issue or aspect?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, because the Court of Appeal had no hesitation reaching the takings question.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't think--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, wouldn't you have a reason to disavow the finding that an effort to exhaust administrative remedies would be futile?
You have to rely on that one sentence in which they make reference to the fact that actually the property owner never did apply for any administrative relief.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: But surely, earlier they said, didn't have to because it'd be futile to do it.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Well, they said earlier in a decision that it's wiped off the books and no longer exists.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: But you have to... you really have to build everything on that one sentence, don't you?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: As far as interpreting what the Court of Appeal, was the basis of its ruling, that's all we have, and it's not entirely clear.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Now, you think that the complaint in this case challenged the constitutionality of a local ordinance?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Of a local ordinance?
It did.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: So that you think this is a proper appeal here?
Aside from finality questions it's a proper appeal in the sense that the state court rejected a claim that a local ordinance was unconstitutional in the Federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't think it's a proper appeal from the standpoint that I think the taking question can't be answered until there is an #.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I understand that, but that's just that there isn't any final judgment on the taking issue.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But there was a straightforward challenge to a local ordinance on the constitutional grounds?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, there was.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Are you suggesting that they can do--
--Does the complaint even mention the Federal Constitution?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I don't recall specifically if the complaint mentions--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: I don't think it does.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --mentions the Federal Constitution.
It may just say constitutional deprivation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It doesn't even say that.
Are you suggesting the power company can do now in the trial court everything it could have done back in 1973 or '74?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: It could have... could do in a trial court?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: No, can get whatever relief it could have gotten initially?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Certainly, I think they could.
Oh, is what you're driving at is the business about whether money damages are appropriate?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Broad.
Can they get whatever they could get in the beginning?
Have any of these interim decisions foreclosed them of any right they had in 1973?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: On the question of damages, let me answer it this way, Your Honor.
And I think that's the only particular question where that statement would be--
No, there is probably some difference as a result of the Court of Appeal and the California Supreme Court's decision in Agins.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: May I ask another question before you take up another point?
If we should conclude that Findings 29 and 32 are still before us, would you agree that there has been a taking?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: No, I would not agree that there has been a taking.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Would you develop that a little bit?
One finding states that no practical use can be made of the property.
The other states that it would be futile to make any application for further administrative relief.
At that point you have a property owner with property that is apparently worthless.
Why hasn't there been a taking?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Well, we have to be careful in the sense of how we're using the phrase, "taking".
And I think that gets back to the confusion from this Court's early decision in the Penn Coal case.
There may very well be a taking from a due process standpoint under the Fourteenth Amendment, a denial of property without due process of law.
But if you're meaning a taking from the eminent domain sense, that's where our position is that there is a distinction.
And I think there seems to me to be a lot of confusion by decisions on the tendency to blur the two distinct powers, the police power and the power of eminent domain.
They are not, it's not a difference in degree.
--Excuse me.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Just so I can understand you, you think that if a state or one of its subdivisions characterizes its action as an exercise of a police power, then the compensation clause is inapplicable?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Your Honor, it's not how we characterize, it's not how we characterize it.

It's whether or not we are regulating through land use means and telling the landowner what uses may not occur or may be prohibited as... and that's the police power, as opposed to the power of eminent domain, which is, we are taking your property for public use.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
