turn.text: But what if you, in doing so, you denominate what we are doing is simply exercising the police power, the control of safety, health, and morals of the populace?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Well if it's not exercising the police power, then it doesn't matter what we call it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Which leaves you--
--Well, what about Pennsylvania Coal v. Mahon, where there was very stringent regulations.
The Court said, this crosses the line, this is a taking, in spite of the fact that the State has called it a regulation.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but the Court did not award money damages and title to the property.
They said that the police power regulation could not stand up or it would constitute a taking.
And the Constitution is satisfied if the restriction is not enforced or wiped off the books.
And so--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, then, is it your view, Mr. Sumption, that this sentence which seems to me the dispositive holding of the Court of Appeal, that
"A local entity's arbitrary unconstitutional exercise of the police power which deprives the owner of the beneficial use of his land does not require compensation. "

that that language contains a negative pregnant, so to speak, a negative implication that a local entity's rational and constitutional exercise of the police power, which deprives the owner of the beneficial use of his land, does require compensation?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --I don't think it does, Your Honor, not at all.
Not under... this Court has never found that a regulation can be transmuted into--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, what if it is, in fact?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --The only way it could be is if there is some physical occupation or use of the property, because--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That's not true.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --Well, there's no taking in an eminent domain sense, only in the due process sense.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, in an eminent domain sense, government could take property and then leave it undeveloped for years.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Well, we're speaking of taking in two complete different senses.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Sumption, let me put Mr. Justice Stewart's question somewhat differently.

Suppose you owned, say, 50 acres of quite scenic property and the City had simply adopted an ordinance saying that, we would zone that property as a natural habitat for animals and fauna and the flora; never put anything on it, we're just going to zone it for that purpose.
But the public may wander through it, may fish in the ponds, may make such use as it wishes.
Are you saying there would be no taking?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: No.
I think that's what I'm trying to say is the distinguishing factor.
If we somehow give the public the right to go on private property, then I think you've--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: You just give the public a right to look at it.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Just to look at it, as they drive by it on the freeway.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes.
As long as the landowner can make a use of his property, we have not taken it for public land.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: No, you say he can't make any use of it.
He can't develop it at all.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: But he can.
We're not physically taking the property away from him.
If you mean, by no use, that he can't go on his own property, that's one thing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Mr. Sumption, I wonder why you weren't satisfied with just defending the judgment of the Court of Appeal?
Don't you consider you've won the case?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I am satisfied.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, would you be satisfied if we affirmed on the grounds that the California courts have held that the landowner was wholly deprived of the use of his property and we accept those findings, but that in a sense that we agree with the Agins decision of the Supreme Court of California?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: I would be satisfied if this Court affirmed the ruling of the Court of Appeal below.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But the California Court of Appeal has not held that there was no taking.
It says that remains open for the utility if it desires to retry the case and produce new evidence, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Right.
Yes, Your Honor.
May I make one comment, because I know my time is running out?

The other misleading thing is that the appellants are trying to say that scope of the California Supreme Court's decision in Agins, which is relied on and cited in this Court of Appeal opinion, that the remedy is equitable relief, not money damages, where a taking through governmental regulation has occurred.
The case is not absolute.
Counsel for appellant portrays it in his brief as though the California Supreme Court has created some sort of immunity.
The California Supreme Court has still left the door open for money damages in land use cases in certain circumstances.
One would be unreasonable precondemnation conduct.

That is, a public entity wants to buy the property and they start, you know, doing things with an illicit motive in order to reduce the value so when we do get around to buying it we pay much less than what the property would otherwise be worth.

The other situation, the California Supreme Court has said, where there is a denial of access to the property, they have still left open the door to money damages on that theory and where there is special and direct interference with the landowner's use of the property.
And there is no evidence or facts on the record, even the findings of fact, there are no findings to that effect, that we have frustrated any use of... or refused a use to develop the property.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, suppose the California Supreme Court or all the courts in California declare the zoning statute unconstitutional as applied to this piece of property, that the City has unconstitutionally interfered with the use of this property.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Now, has the California Supreme Court or the Court of Appeal precluded damages in that situation?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Under those facts, without any actual use, without the other factors, denial of access or any direct and special interference with the landowner's attempt to use the property, I think that's a correct assessment, that the California Supreme Court would say, no, your remedy is to set aside the regulations.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, they get set aside but meanwhile the landowner has not been able to use it for the purpose he wanted.
The zoning ordinance has effectively precluded his use of the property and the Supreme Court has said so.
No damages?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: No damages, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: You say that's police power, not Fifth Amendment taking?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: In California, that's the rule--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, California is a part of the United States, isn't it?

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: --I understand that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.

turn.speaker: c_alan_sumption
turn.label: Mr. C. Alan Sumption
turn.text: Thank you, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The case is submitted.
